bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, [January 9, 1947?]

div1.p: Lambert corrects a draft of an interview of Lambert by Hench - conducted on June 21, 1946. He also tries to advance his case for being included in the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, [January 9, 1947?]
div1.p:
Lamberts corrections of our
Interview of June 21, 1946

I have received the papers many thank
but two copies of letters that Andrus
sent to senators Sheppard and Lewis
were missing

I have read over printed interview! I know my
english is poor, and pronouncing faulty. but
even so, the young lady could had made a litle
less garbling I have to point out page by page

Board consisted of officers only, Kissinger and Forbes I
couldn't have said were members of Board or
commission, they were men who took part in
the experiment! wastwasn't there mentioned that Ames told
me I might soon be out if Grayham happened to be
the only patient when I told Ames I did not care to
go in quarantine as I had 7 1/2 months of it at Nos. 1.Military Hosp

Maj. Kean came in the morning Hepburn at night
I so stated

I did not say may you go and tell the Doctor, that
would have been insolent or disrespectful I had
no Idea of being so, but to follow the Doctors orders
I know Doctor Hench that if you had the
president for a patient you would insist the
nurse took orders from you not from the patient.
I said I was going to put it back in the glass, I did
not have time to put it back before the storm brook.
I did not say that Ames shut the door knowing
it would have been absolutely dark, there was
no window

I did not say, never had time to wash floor, I
had pleanty of time with only two patient
I did say I couldn't wash the floor (meaning the
way it should be washed) just throw water and
let dirty water run down, boards being so far
apart I could put my hand between them
I couldn't have said a man but the man (meaning
the one in charge of Depot (Steward Pike)

Surely I couldn't have been foolish enough
to mention Dr Stark as one who could have
been transefered in place of Dr Ames Stark
was post Surgeon I did mention Amador
or Cook

Transeferred I think Aug 7th
Prisoners sent from Pinar Del Rio to Columbia
Barracks when claiming sickness sent to receiving
ward at hospital I was not gaurding them,
there was no guard sent with them, or posted
with them.

I remember I couldn't tell directions I'll draw
the buildings as used

all of the patients taken care of in this
bldg except 8 marked in other bldg
If messured with tape I think it would check

Dr Ames did not put the women to work because
we had no female patients, after Mrs Hunt left
they were sent down for the purpose of caring
for femal patients... Here the young lady got her
notes mixed I certainly did not say that we put
the Doctor who took Dr Ames place in 116 as a
patient. I put Ames in 13 (Folk and Forbes was
in 115) and when Andrus came in the day
after Ames took sick the new Doctor put Andrus
in 116 and made the women move in to 114:
They were all sick that were down there, but only
one had black vomit I did not say some of them
the black vomit case I told you about at 4718 Wood-
lawn ave. Maj Gorgas told the man (Old Sullivan)
he was the only man he ever seen who at his age
have had black vomit 3 times and recovered

The lady have a habbit of using plural where singu-
lar should be used, where an inciden happened
once and so stated she has made it appear as being
common practise, Colby was on his 6th class, and
over the hump as one might say Sergt Ryan was
on his 3rd day and very nervous, it's hard to
sleep with one eye open when real tired and
I tied a string to Colby's bed and to my tumb
before laying back in chair and asking him to
give it a yank in case Ryan called and I didn't
hear, there was only one realy sick soldier

I did not say that Amador, Albertino and
Findlay came to see the patients or Maj Kean
while he was sick Albertino and Amador
came to see Kissinger the first day only, and I
said it was Amador who put his head
under Kissingers blanket. Autopsy was held
in an old Messhall, not old hospital. When I
wrote Agramonte and asked him if in
his opinion Maj Reed considered autopsy's more
dangerous then soiled clothing, in view of the
fact that he stood so far away, that letter
would never have been writen except for
the question mentioned I showed you the
reply I had from Agramonte wherin he said,
Maj Reed did not consider autopsy table
dangerous but that it is on record that yellow
fever epidemics have started from contact
with soiled clothing. The battery toof which the
man had been a member, and 7th Cav. band
about 200 lbs

Dr Carroll was in Officers quarters not ward! stable
lantern, I couldn't have said doorman as there
were none I said I woke first Maj Reed and then
Carroll. they, Maj Reed and Carroll took some
slides along not we and they, not we punched
ear and finger I only rubbed off with alcohol
and cotton

Mrs. Gillen said when she came after me in
big ward (Bldg 115) he was acting awful Forbes
and Folk were in 115 Miss Lewis was taking care
of Dr Ames up in the Officers ward page 14. Dr Ames.
order was, that water taken and urin passed should
average the same every four hours, or hold back
on water. No I did not catherize any dead men
I said I had one that I used on the man who died
I suppose I mentioned that because he was the
only one I needed to use it on up to that time.
Andrus was on his knees with head dug in pillow
I said to Dr Ames “I wish you could come down”
Dr Ames then said, can't you see I am sick in bed
myself! we haven't had a death yet amongst experimental
cases! with his permission I got a man

to the question who took care of Dr Ames I can't
remember my answer but I know after he
was cleaned out he got no more medicine and
Maj Reed looked in to see him whenever he came
down I really don't know if Dr who took Ames place
looked in to see him. After arriving at
officers ward he was a patient of Dr Stark

Dr Stark signed Ames' release not relief
Dr Ames told me Dr Carroll was awfully
sick you go up there and help them (I was sent
as we had no patient in pest house at that time)
What I actually said was that Dr Carroll laying
on his elbow, with left foot on floor right foot on
bed intending to get up

Nurse standing on right side of bed
Dr Lazear worked his head off, not looking his
head off.

I can't remember that case history records were
mentioned, I would have been entirely in the
wrong if giving opinion who wrote them as
I had no way of knowing, the charts I saw
Lottie working, copying some of them

I was born 1874 not 1884, tried to enlist in
Navy but an account of what Doctors both in
Scotland, Germany, Sweden, Philadelphia and
examining Doctor in Navy said rupture (he
saw mark of truss) I later joined Hosp Corps for
what was promissed as philipine service Doctor
Stark took one look and said undescended
testicle (I did not like to mention this
with a young lady present) I was the last man
Dr Stark operated an in Cuba Dr Stark
sent me to ask Maj Keans permission as he had
taken over temporarily the past after Dr Stark
I voluntered when Maj Carter asked if there was
any immunes or any one who wasn't afraid of
yellow fever no one was detailed or ordered to
work were there was fear of yellow fever volunteers
plants
was asked for. In one of disinfection is wrong
there was only one

I realize the officers named contributed a lot to
the success of the experiment but they did so in a
material way both Gen Wood and Maj Kean was
at that time immunes and would have been in
no danger if entering the pest house Bill 13060 was
passed to compensate those who exposed themselfs
to loss of health or life Officers of the Board for
their scientific work, men for serving beyond
the line of duty. If work in pest house was not
outside the line of duty then why couldn't a man
have been detailed there, when I asked Dr Ames
what will I do with the disinfection plant (that
was considered so necessary at this time) he
said I need a man down there at once close
the plant which was doen. The only difference
I can see is that I voluntered for work
beyond the line of duty before any one els and
I did so without promise of extra pay. I
know the men who took fomites test felt they were
there trying to get yellow fever, but none of them
had black vomit spewed right on their heads
like old Sullivan did to me Maj Gorgas stood at
head of bed and grabbed a towel and threw
over my head so I could wipe my face and
asked if I had any disinfectant I realize the
man wasn't an experimental case but some
of his black vomit was sent up for the use of the
Board Senator Thomas in his report to the
Senate (He being chairman of committee) wrote
this man should have quit when first case of experi-
mental yellow fever came in. I would then
have been asked to Volunteer to take care of them
It has been pointed out that Dr Ames was only the
physician for the commission if such was the case
he certainly laid himself open to criminal
prosecution when he injected contaminated
blood into a healthy person I don't know but
what I could have been held. as an asessory to the
crime At the time Dr Ames drew blood from
Martinez to be injected into jernegan he
had a wadd of cotton and himself rubbed
the arm of Martinez, but told me to clean
of a spot under left shoulder on jernegan,
at this particular time Dr Ames spoke the only
harsh words he ever used toward me in the
two years I worked under him, he said “I did not
tell you to take his hide off I only asked you
to clean a part” it wasn't the words he used it
was the way he said it, I suppose he was nervous,
I know several persons have tried to get on the
band wagon through Bill 13060 Moore was one he
worked in Camp Lazear, handled dirty clothing
he claimes when helping me in disinfection
plant experiment was then ended Apr 1901, another
was Schwieger he had yellow fever 7 months before
experiment started, his claim is that he helped to
take care of Lazear, he helped only one day, and was
an immune Neet who worked in laboratory I
believe is one (or was one) the most deadly poison
is handled in both laboratories and chemical
plants but its harmless when handled properly,
it would have been the mans own fault if
he had been bitten by infected mosquitose
I have read photostatic copy of letter from Maj
Reed to Dr Ames after Maj Reed had induced
Surg Gen to give Ames the rank of Major
Andrus wrote me it was easyer for war dept to throw out all bills
then to investigate
From what I've learned from Mrs Ames
Dr Ames commanded the hospital detachment
at Army Post near New Orleans, just as Dr Stark
commanded hospital at Columbia barrack,
Lt. Litte commanded Post as did Col Baldwin
at Columbia Barrack. That is information I
received from Mrs Ames

I have made every thing as clear as I know how, I have
tried to show my version of things, if I have showed
eagerness in proving my point I'm glad to say I have never
wanted to make my point so much that I were
willing to lie to make it. Neither have I ever wanted
anything so bad that I wanted to steal it.

Sorry it has taken me so long in sending back
the papers, but when reading glass have to be used
most of the time work goes slowly I'm afraid my
reading will soon end

Gust. E. Lambert
8009 Avalon ave.
Chicago 19 Ill
